awd_titl_txt: Geoinformatics Facility: Integration of alphaMELTS petrologic software with flexible modeling environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists investigate the generation and evolution of magma (molten rock) with a range of tools such as field-based studies, experiments at high pressures and temperatures, and models of the physical and chemical behavior of partially molten rocks. The modeling component is particularly important for situations where field work is too hazardous or inaccessible and where it would take too many experiments to fully describe the processes leading to a catastrophic volcanic eruption. This work focuses on continuing development of a flexible, powerful, and easy-to-use package of modeling software used by hundreds of Earth scientists. The alphaMELTS 2 software can model complex scenarios with changing pressure, temperature, and chemical composition while monitoring energy and mass of major and trace elements and gaseous species. This project will increase the mineral systems alphaMELTS 2 can model, support users, extend applications of the software in teaching and training, and facilitate outreach workshops to train new users. These workshops will reach several dozen users, mostly early-career scientists, and equip them with quantitative tools for modern petrology research.

There are several particular advances on which this effort will focus, mostly new thermodynamic model calibrations for use with alphaMELTS 2 and related tools: modeling of CO2 in mantle magmatic systems; the amphibole mineral group; the biotite mineral group; more flexible treatment of trace elements; better integration with MATLAB, Python, and other development environments; and user interaction and training through the online forum and dedicated training workshops. Extension of the calibration strategy to exploit new categories of experiments such as two-liquid equilibria, will allow the pMELTS code for high-pressure melting to describe carbon-bearing systems such as subducted carbonate or upwelling carbonated mantle rocks. The most widespread and important igneous minerals that are not well-modeled in current generations of MELTS are amphibole and biotite; a new strategy will be implemented that can tackle the great complexity of naturally occurring amphiboles and make an accurate yet tractable calibration. Dynamically loadable libraries that allow for seamless incorporation of all alphaMELTS 2 functionality into any Fortran, C++, Matlab or Python code will enable coupling with other codes and flexible scripting. Finally, a large expansion of the phases and trace elements that can be treated with variable and modular partition coefficients will allow users to customize their trace element calculations for greater accuracy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Igneous petrology, the study of rocks formed by cooling of magma, addresses problems including the temperature and composition of the Earth's interior over time, volcanic hazards, the formation of magmatic ore deposits, and more. Scientists working in this area collect field and laboratory observations but they depend on computational models to test their data against hypotheses, because igneous processes occur at depth in the Earth, where we cannot observe them directly. The accuracy and ease-of-use of available computational models is therefore a key limiting factor in scientific progress and discovery of new knowledge in this area (as in many other fields). This Geoinformatics award funded the ongoing development, maintenance, and user support of a software package we call alphaMELTS, which enables the US and world scientific community to predict the outcomes of complex geological processes involving the melting of rocks and crystallization of magma. The "facility" award recognized that there were already several hundred users of the software; as we finish the award the user base has grown further, with frequent new downloads and a steady stream of publications citing the software.

Some of our work under this project focused on aspects of software engineering and maintenance, such as keeping up with changing operating systems and chipsets or migrating from proprietary software to entirely open-source software. Another aspect of our work centered on supporting users by answering their questions, debugging their installations, or suggesting the best ways to model the problems they were trying to solve. Over the four-year span of the award, we hosted numerous workshops to train users — ranging from undergraduate students to senior scientists — in how to install and use the alphaMELTS and related software packages. In turn many of these attendees put the software to work in their own publications, maximizing the impact of this project in moving the scientific enterprise forwards.

The supported work was not just software development, maintenance, and distribution, however. We also worked on extending the model by adding new chemical components (e.g. CO2) or more complete descriptions of minerals (notably the amphibole group), and we applied the model ourselves in a series of papers focusing on various problems in igneous and economic geology. We focused especially on the igneous rocks of the Arabian-Nubian Shield, which outcrops in Egypt and Saudi Arabia and hosts a series of metal-rich igneous intrusions and volcanic provinces that are not easily explained by conventional plate tectonic processes.

Several PhD students were supported by this award and completed or made progress towards their degrees thanks to their research, which in turn contributed to improving or applying the alphaMELTS software.
